scope: AQA GCSE Chemistry - Common student misconceptions

items.pattern: Reduction is loss of electrons.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! In electron-transfer redox, reduction is GAIN of electrons, not loss.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Use OILRIG: Reduction Is Gain (of electrons). Loss is oxidation.

items.pattern: Oxidation is gain of electrons.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! In electron-transfer redox, oxidation is LOSS of electrons, not gain.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Use OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss (of electrons). Gain is reduction.

items.pattern: Metal + acid → salt + water
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! Acid + metal produces hydrogen gas, NOT water. Water is produced in neutralisation with bases/alkalis.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Metal + acid → salt + hydrogen. Test the hydrogen with lit splint (squeaky pop).

items.pattern: It relights a glowing splint.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! That's the oxygen test. Hydrogen gives a squeaky pop with a LIT (burning) splint.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Hydrogen test: lit splint → squeaky pop. Oxygen test: relights glowing splint.

items.pattern: Oxidation means the metal loses oxygen.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! In oxygen-transfer terms, oxidation is GAIN of oxygen, not loss.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Oxidation (oxygen-transfer) = gain oxygen. Reduction = loss oxygen. Example: metal + oxygen → metal oxide (metal is oxidised).

items.pattern: Reduction means gaining oxygen.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! In oxygen-transfer terms, reduction is LOSS of oxygen, not gain.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Reduction (oxygen-transfer) = loss of oxygen. Example: metal oxide → metal (oxide is reduced).

items.pattern: M + H2O → MOH + H2
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! This is not balanced. You need 2 of each to balance the hydrogen atoms.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Correct balanced equation: 2M + 2H₂O → 2MOH + H₂

items.pattern: Zinc + iron chloride → iron chloride + zinc
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! That keeps the same substances on both sides - no reaction! Displacement means the metals swap positions.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Zinc + iron chloride → zinc chloride + iron. The more reactive zinc displaces the iron.

items.pattern: Group 1 metals get less reactive down the group.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! Group 1 metals get MORE reactive going down the group, not less.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Group 1 reactivity: Li < Na < K. Outer electron gets further from nucleus = easier to lose = more reactive.

items.pattern: Halogens get more reactive down the group.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Halogens get LESS reactive going down the group (opposite to Group 1).
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Halogen reactivity: F > Cl > Br > I. Outer shell gets further from nucleus = harder to gain electron = less reactive.

items.pattern: Acid + base → salt + hydrogen
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! Neutralisation produces water, not hydrogen. Only acid + metal produces hydrogen.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Acid + base → salt + water. Acid + metal → salt + hydrogen.

items.pattern: Strong acid means concentrated acid.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Strong/weak refers to ionisation, concentrated/dilute refers to amount of acid per volume.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Strong = completely ionises. Weak = partially ionises. You can have strong dilute acid or weak concentrated acid.

items.pattern: pH 7 is alkaline.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! pH 7 is neutral, not alkaline. Alkaline is above pH 7.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: pH < 7 = acidic, pH = 7 = neutral, pH > 7 = alkaline.

items.pattern: Inert means reactive.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! Inert means UNreactive, not reactive.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Inert = unreactive. Noble gases are inert because they have full outer shells.

items.pattern: Spectator ions change during the reaction.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Spectator ions DON'T change - they stay the same throughout.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Spectator ions remain unchanged (same charge, same state). They're omitted from ionic equations.

items.pattern: Carbon can extract any metal from its ore.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Carbon can only extract metals LESS reactive than itself (below carbon in reactivity series).
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Metals above carbon (K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, Al) need electrolysis. Metals below carbon can be extracted by reduction with carbon.

items.pattern: Electrolysis is cheaper than reduction with carbon.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Electrolysis is MUCH more expensive - it requires continuous electrical energy.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Carbon reduction is cheap (just heat). Electrolysis is very expensive (continuous electricity).

items.pattern: Metals form negative ions.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Metals form POSITIVE ions (cations) by losing electrons.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Metals lose electrons → positive ions. Non-metals gain electrons → negative ions.

items.pattern: The period tells you the number of outer electrons.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! The GROUP tells you the outer electrons. The PERIOD tells you the number of electron shells.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Group number = outer electrons (for groups 1-7). Period number = number of shells.

items.pattern: Acid + metal carbonate → salt + carbon dioxide only
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! You're missing water! Acid + carbonate produces THREE products: salt, water, AND carbon dioxide.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Acid + metal carbonate → salt + water + carbon dioxide

items.pattern: Native metals are combined with other elements.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! Native means NOT combined - found as pure element.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Native = found as pure metal, not combined with other elements. Only very unreactive metals (Au, Ag) are found native.

items.pattern: All Group 1 metals explode with water.
items.whyWrong: Easy mistake to make! Only the most reactive ones (like caesium) explode. Lithium, sodium, and potassium react vigorously but with different intensities.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: Li fizzes gently, Na melts and moves quickly, K melts and ignites with lilac flame. Reactivity increases down the group.

items.pattern: pH decrease of 1 means H+ concentration doubles.
items.whyWrong: This is a common mix-up! pH is logarithmic - pH decrease of 1 means H+ concentration increases by factor of 10, not 2.
items.correctGuidance: Here's the correct way: pH decrease of 1 = H+ concentration ×10. pH decrease of 2 = H+ concentration ×100.
